frameDefinitions: The words in this frame refer to what Clothing the Wearer (or a specific Body_part of the Wearer) has on.
This frame concerns people's knowledge or skill in certain domains.
An Entity is presented as having been seen or experienced by a (typically generic and backgrounded)
An entity is considered worthy of mention for their ability or influence among some Type of similar entities.
This frame concerns an Evaluee being judged for its quality, i.e. how much it would probably be liked.
A Cognizer has a piece of Content in their model of the world.
frameExamples: I <t>had</t> <t>on</t> the most ridiculous monkey-suit you could imagine.
FE Layer-1: He is an <t>experienced</t> programmer.
Susanna Fulton's work is <t>new</t> to me.
Dali is one of the <t>great</t> artists of the 20th century.
Your boss is <t>aware</t> of your commitment.
listRoleDefinitions: The person whose clothing is under discussion.
This role identifies the <fen>Clothing</fen> that the <fen>Wearer</fen> wears.
The body part of the <fen>Wearer</fen> which is covered by the <fen>Clothing</fen>.
The time at or during which the <fen>Wearer</fen> has the <fen>Clothing</fen> on.
The person whose expertise is assessed.
<fen>Skill</fen> identifies the <fen>Protagonist</fen>'s talent or ability to do things with one's hand or body.
The area of knowledge (as opposed to a practical skill) in which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> 's experience is assessed.
A  product of behavior that shows the <fen>Protagonist</fen>'s skill or lack of skill.

This frame element can only occur in place of a skill expression. It refers to the prototypical patient in an action involving the Protagonist. For instance, in the following sentence  the children are experts at some (contextually given) action such as rolling the hoops.

<fex name='Protagonist'>Some children</fex> <m>were</m> <fex name='Degree'>quite</fex> <t>expert</t> <fex name='Focal_participant'>with wooden hoops</fex>.
This frame element denotes a role in which the protagonist has developed his expertise.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Protagonist</fen> has the expertise.
A concrete thing or abstract phenomenon or fact that is assessed in terms of how well recognizable it is to a <fen>Cognizer</fen>.
The (typically non-specific and backgrounded) sentient being for whom the <fen>Entity</fen> possesses a specified level of recognizability.
The deviation of the actual level of recognizability of the <fen>Entity</fen> from the level specified by the target.
The kind of thing which is notable. This may be an event, place, item, or role and is plural.
The name of the notable entity.
The time during which the entity is considered notable.
The geographic area in which the entity is considered notable.
The <fen>Evaluee</fen> is being judged for its quality.
This role marks expressions that denote a scalar property of the <fen>Evaluee</fen> with respect to which the <fen>Evaluee</fen> is judged.

The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person whose awareness of phenomena is at question. With a target verb or adjective the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is generally expressed as an External Argument with the <fen>Content</fen> expressed as an Object or Complement.
The <fen>Content</fen> is the object of the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s awareness. <fen>Content</fen> can be expressed as a direct object or in a PP Complement.
Some verbs in this frame allow a <fen>Topic</fen> to be expressed in about-PPs.
<fen>Expressor</fen> is the body part that reveals the <fen>Cognizer</fen>'s state to the observer.
The time interval during which the <fen>Cognizer</fen> is aware of the <fen>Content</fen>.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Fred</fex> was shirtless.
Fred was wearing <fex>a shirt</fex>.
She was wearing a glove <fex>on one hand</fex>.
<fex>By five o'clock</fex>, he was wearing the old holey jeans and t-shirt again.
A skillful <fex>advertising campaign</fex> persuaded voters that his opponent was soft on crime.
His prowess <fex>as a surgeon</fex> is impressive.
He gave <fex>an address</fex> quite familiar to the chauffeur.
The information used to illustrate the concept is familiar <fex>to the reader</fex>.
He gave an address <fex>quite</fex> familiar to the chauffeur.
Shakespeare is one of the great <fex>poets</fex>.
<fex>Shakespeare</fex> is one of the great poets.
Bob Dylan is among the most notable musicians <fex>of the 20th century</fex>.
Dumas is one of the most notable authors <fex>in France</fex>.
He gave me another lame <fex>excuse</fex>.
The Beaujolais Nouveau is dazzling <fex>in freshness</fex>.
<fex>Your boss</fex> is aware of your commitment.
Your boss is aware <fex>of your commitment</fex>.
Kim knows <fex>about first aid</fex>.
Bob's <fex>eyes</fex> were overly aware

Yet there is no evidence that Mr. Parrish was cognizant <fex>at the time of the signing
of the notes</fex> that the clauses in issue were present.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: Firestarter Vol. 1: The Quest For Fire
